Friday, February 16, 1934

Carefully-Veiled Praise

Letters To The Editor
Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir,
After perusing three (may I call them theses?)
in your columns recently on the subject of "higher education", I must confess that I am still very much
(to use "lower education" jargon) "up in the air"
as to just what higher education really is.
This condition is really a sad state of affairs, for
I have been a follower (ardent, too) of education for
lo, these many years, and had adopted a sort of smug
satisfaction that I knew what it was all about and
that education—high or low—was something to be
greatly cherished by any person who had a yen for
arriving at the top of the heap in this vale of tears.
Now, however, after stumbling through the entangled, high-sounding verbiage of Kemler, et al., I
suppose I will have to drop my complacency and start
with feverish haste (hurry, to you, Kemler, etc.),
to read all the dictionaries and lexicographies to determine the meaning, first of some of the verbs and
adverbs used by our three illustrious contributors to
see if they are really included in the English language, and if not, from whence they were culled.
If higher education consists of such rubbish as
these three gallant pen-wielders would have me believe, I may as well throw away my books and rent
a pick and shovel and a pair or two of overalls and go
to work at something not quite so complicated. For
after all, the attainment of a higher education as described by t. t. g. p-w.'s would only mean misery to
the average human being.
Maybe I am taking them too seriously. Maybe
after all they were just writing to fill space. Maybe
they do understand what higher education is all about.
Maybe they don't.
Maybe if they tried to put into practice their
theories spread on the pages of THE NEWS-LETTER,
there would not have been any articles on higher education, for they would have been so busy looking up
nonsensical words they would not have found time to
use up all that printer's ink.
Maybe it doesn't mean anything after all (I
mean "higher education").
Yours for the upholding of the present standards
of education, wherein a man's a man and a diploma
is a sheepskin.
—R. A. Z.

There is little question but that we're bucking the
esprit de corps of the Hopkins undergraduates; but
we'll take the bit in our teeth, so to speak, and direct
an enthusiastic slap at the backs of the Blue Jay
basketball quint. Mixed metaphors or not, the boys
are good.
If legend does not misinform us, athletes count
tremendously upon moral support. Judging by that
standard the Hopkins teams are beaten before they
start because we simply are not interested in winning
games or making a good showing. There's no explaining it (and who wants to know, anyway?) ;
we're just that way. So, that for the court squad to
come from away behind to second among seven state
teams, indicates something creditable.
Nor have the team members been exempt from
the difficulties of the whole athletic tangle as locally
manifested. Inadequate equipment, no home gymnasium for practicing, and coaching difficulties have
all combined with general indifference to discourage
any over-exuberance which the cagers might have

Friday, February 16, 1934

Carefully-Veiled Praise

Letters To The Editor
Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir,
After perusing three (may I call them theses?)
in your columns recently on the subject of "higher education", I must confess that I am still very much
(to use "lower education" jargon) "up in the air"
as to just what higher education really is.
This condition is really a sad state of affairs, for
I have been a follower (ardent, too) of education for
lo, these many years, and had adopted a sort of smug
satisfaction that I knew what it was all about and
that education—high or low—was something to be
greatly cherished by any person who had a yen for
arriving at the top of the heap in this vale of tears.
Now, however, after stumbling through the entangled, high-sounding verbiage of Kemler, et al., I
suppose I will have to drop my complacency and start
with feverish haste (hurry, to you, Kemler, etc.),
to read all the dictionaries and lexicographies to determine the meaning, first of some of the verbs and
adverbs used by our three illustrious contributors to
see if they are really included in the English language, and if not, from whence they were culled.
If higher education consists of such rubbish as
these three gallant pen-wielders would have me believe, I may as well throw away my books and rent
a pick and shovel and a pair or two of overalls and go
to work at something not quite so complicated. For
after all, the attainment of a higher education as described by t. t. g. p-w.'s would only mean misery to
the average human being.
Maybe I am taking them too seriously. Maybe
after all they were just writing to fill space. Maybe
they do understand what higher education is all about.
Maybe they don't.
Maybe if they tried to put into practice their
theories spread on the pages of THE NEWS-LETTER,
there would not have been any articles on higher education, for they would have been so busy looking up
nonsensical words they would not have found time to
use up all that printer's ink.
Maybe it doesn't mean anything after all (I
mean "higher education").
Yours for the upholding of the present standards
of education, wherein a man's a man and a diploma
is a sheepskin.
—R. A. Z.

There is little question but that we're bucking the
esprit de corps of the Hopkins undergraduates; but
we'll take the bit in our teeth, so to speak, and direct
an enthusiastic slap at the backs of the Blue Jay
basketball quint. Mixed metaphors or not, the boys
are good.
If legend does not misinform us, athletes count
tremendously upon moral support. Judging by that
standard the Hopkins teams are beaten before they
start because we simply are not interested in winning
games or making a good showing. There's no explaining it (and who wants to know, anyway?) ;
we're just that way. So, that for the court squad to
come from away behind to second among seven state
teams, indicates something creditable.
Nor have the team members been exempt from
the difficulties of the whole athletic tangle as locally
manifested. Inadequate equipment, no home gymnasium for practicing, and coaching difficulties have
all combined with general indifference to discourage
any over-exuberance which the cagers might have
